awd_titl_txt: Renewal of Scholarship for Service at California State University, Sacramento (2015-2020)
awd_abstract_narration:
California State University, Sacramento proposes to add four new cohorts of undergraduate and graduate students to their existing CyberCorps(R) Scholarship for Service (SFS) program in cybersecurity. Sacramento State has developed a solid infrastructure for cybersecurity education, including the establishment of both a strong cybersecurity component to the Computer Science program and a Center for Information Assurance and Security (CIAS). The previous NSF funding has helped Sacramento State to establish a strong SFS program and contributed significantly to sustainability of the cybersecurity curriculum. All students who graduated through May 2014 have been placed in qualified government positions. The National Security Agency and the Department of Homeland Security designated Sacramento State's CIAS a National Center of Academic Excellence in Information Assurance Education and Cyber Defense. Participating faculty will attend technical workshops and conferences in cybersecurity, which will allow to disseminate broadly the results of their scholarly activities and maintain currency in this rapidly changing field. In return, faculty will further enhance the depth and scope of research being conducted in cybersecurity.

The SFS project broadens its impact by mentoring community colleges in northern California in their efforts to establish or enhance cybersecurity programs. The project will assist the colleges in developing pathways that reach the region's high schools up to the graduate program in cybersecurity at Sacramento State. This will significantly enhance cybersecurity workforce development in northern California. The project is expected to increase participation of individuals from underrepresented groups in cybersecurity. It has built-in flexibility in the selection process to enhance the acceptance rate of minorities and female candidates into the program. The project includes an assessment and evaluation plan coordinated by an independent evaluator to ensure that the project achieves its objectives. The project's results will be disseminated through conference and professional presentations.

por.por_cntn:
The College of Engineering and Computer Science (ECS) at California State University, Sacramento (Sacramento State) has developed a solid infrastructure for cybersecurity education, including the establishment of both a strong practically-oriented cybersecurity component to the Computer Science program and a Center for Information Assurance and Security (CIAS). The National Security Agency (NSA) and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) designated Sacramento State's CIAS a National Center of Academic Excellence in Information Assurance Education (CAE-IAE) for academic years 2007 - 2012 and again for 2012 - 2017. CIAS was also designated a Center of Academic Excellence in Cyber Defense Education (CAE-CDE) for 2017-2022, and again for 2023-2028.

Through the CyberCorps? Scholarship for Service (SFS) project,  Sacramento State attracted more qualified students to cybersecurity field, increased security education into our curriculum and produced well-prepared graduates that met employers? needs and were successfully placed in various federal and state agencies to date.  The  program successfully recruited 42 students through a competitive selection process. This represents 35 Computer Science and 7 Computer Engineering majors, with 39 pursuing a Bachelor of Science degree and two pursuing a Master of Science degree. The program attracted a significant number of underrepresented minorities, first-generation, and women students. All students graduated within two years of receiving the scholarship. Five students received the Outstanding Graduate Award from the ECS Dean.

Sacramento State achieved a high post-graduation placement rate of 94%. Our graduates secured employment at 1) federal executive agencies such as the National Security Agency (NSA), US Navy divisions including Naval Air Systems Command, Department of Transportation, Department of Interior, Department of Energy National labs including Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL), Los Alamos National Lab (LANL), Idaho National Lab, and Lawrence Livermore National Lab (LLNL); 2) various departments in the State of California; and 3) a few local government agencies. Our students have also completed summer internship following their first year with agencies such as the Department of Homeland Security, NSA, US Navy divisions, LANL, LLNL, PNNL, and the Federal Reserve Bank (FRB) in San Francisco. One hundred percent (100%) of students were placed in internships.

The project enhanced faculty currency through development activities. It enabled faculty members to keep abreast of advances in cybersecurity by participating in  conferences, workshops, or regional competitions and by disseminating broadly the results of their research and scholarly activities as peer-reviewed papers.   In turn, faculty enhanced the quality of information assurance curriculum at Sacramento State based on their development activities.  This further enhanced the depth and scope of research being conducted in cybersecurity-related fields at Sacramento State, leading to integration of  more cybersecurity security topics in computer science courses at Sacramento State, benefiting SFS and non-SFS students alike. 

The program engaged students in multiple research and competition activities. To name a few, eight students (including three SFS students) were hired as student research assistants in secure programming projects, 19 undergraduate students (including five SFS students) were supervised for cybersecurity research projects, 18 graduate students were advised for student research projects, and 28 students (including 13 SFS students) were coached for cybersecurity competitions.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/15/2023
Modified by: Behnam S Arad
